question.name: 23.6.2a Revision of the exponential form of a complex number
question.questiontext:
Adding the results from the previous task gives \[e^{i\pi/6} + e^{-i\pi/6} = 2\cos \left( \dfrac{\pi}{6} \right) \] or \[ \cos \left( \dfrac{\pi}{6} \right) = \dfrac{1}{2} \left( e^{i\pi/6} + e^{-i\pi/6} \right) .\] Subtracting the results from the previous task gives \[e^{i\pi/6} - e^{-i\pi/6} = 2 i \sin \left( \dfrac{\pi}{6} \right) \] or \[ \sin \left( \dfrac{\pi}{6} \right) = \dfrac{1}{2i} \left( e^{i\pi/6} - e^{-i\pi/6} \right) .\] Don't forget the factor \(i\) in this latter case.

Clearly, similar calculations could be carried out for any angle \(\theta\). The general results are summarised in the following Key Point.

Key Point

Euler's Relations

\[ e^{i\theta} \equiv \cos\theta + i \sin \theta, \hspace{1cm} e^{-i\theta} \equiv \cos\theta - i \sin \theta\] \[\cos \theta \equiv \dfrac{1}{2} ( e^{i\theta} + e^{-i\theta} ), \hspace{1cm} \sin \theta \equiv \dfrac{1}{2i} ( e^{i\theta} - e^{-i\theta} )\]

Using these results we can redraft an expression of the form \[ a_n \cos n\theta + b_n \sin n\theta \] in terms of complex exponentials.

(This expression, with \(\omega = \omega_0 t\), is of course the \(n^{ \text{th} }\) harmonic of a trigonometric Fourier series.)
